text: so in Italy we study a lot we do a lot
of grammar and um logic uh structure of
the sentence we study that a lot and we
also study Latin so I'm used to think of
um the language in terms of the
different uh components and I noticed
that maybe that's not so common among uh
students here uh among American or
International students
um so that was a little bit of a
challenge to help them to um to identify
for example the different roles of a
word in a sentence because in the
English language is not so important you
don't have you don't conjugate you don't
change the endings of the adjectives
while in Italian that makes a big
difference so I needed to really help
the students to
identify the this part the structure of
of the phrases that was maybe a little
bit of a challenge but it was I expected
it and also I had a few students who had
learned Spanish before and it's very
since well Italian and Spanish have the
same origin then um I think for them the
Big Challenge was to make the
distinction between the two so it was
easier in a sense to pick up but then um
they had struggled a little to make the
distinction to make a difference
